Detailed Description

a class giving the user access to files on the computer.

This class acts as a virtual representation of the file system. It gives the user direct access to the FS in several different ways. Common functions are implemented as either static members or members accessable via the singleton. Static members make no use of local variables whereas standard member functions do, having a concept of the current directory and a list of resource locations to make finding and opening files easier. The FileSystem also provides factory methods for creation of either a TextFile or a BinaryFile.

Note:
Users can supply a path name in any form, but as a standard convention, all internal path information will be stored with a trailing '/' and either '/' or './' at the front. This is for clarity and consistency.

When passed to the library, or returned from it, a leading './' indicates the path is relative to the working directory of the actual file system.

When passed to the library, or returned from it, a leading '/' indicates the file is relative to the root of the actual file system.

If a path is given to the library without a leading './' or '/' the library's current directory and resource locations will be used. If the operation requires some kind of search to be performed (existence or opening files) the current dir will be checked followed by resource locations. For other operations, the current directory will be prepended to the passed directory. This does not apply to static member functions!

A path retreived from the library will always have a leading './' or '/'.

Author:
Brent Wilson
Date:
May 31, 2007

Member Enumeration Documentation

enum FileSystem::SearchOrder

Enumerates the different search orders allowed when looking for files.

Enumerator:
CurrentDir_ResourceLocs  Seach the current dir, then resource locs.
ResourceLocs_CurrentDir  Seach resource locs, then the current dir.
ResourceLocs  Search just the resource locs.
CurrentDir  Search just the current dir.

enum FileSystem::OpenFlags

Allows certain flags to be set upon ReadFile and WriteFile creation.

Enumerator:
OpenNow  Opens the file immediately
Append  Makes a WriteFile append to existing content.

Member Function Documentation

static string& FileSystem::AddPathDecorations ( string &  path,
bool  isDir 
) [static]

Adds a leading './' if neither a leading './' or '/' is present. It also adds a trailing '/' to the path if it is a directory.

Parameters:
path The path to add decorations to.
isDir True if the given path is a directory.
Returns:
A reference to the given path.

TextFile* FileSystem::openTextFile ( const string &  name,
OpenMode  openFlags = ReadWrite,
SearchOrder  order = CurrentDir_ResourceLocs 
)

Creates a new TextFile based on the given OpenMode and SearchOrder. If the given file doesn't have a leading './' or '/', the file is searched for according to the given SearchOrder. If the file is found that matches the name, a TextFile will be created and returned. If no file is found, one of two things will happen. If the file is opened for writing, a new file will be created in the current working directory, otherwise NULL is returned.

Parameters:
name The name of the file to try and open for reading.
openFlags Flags to be passed to the TextFile constructor.
order Dictates where the library should look for a matching file and the order it should look in. This only matters if the given name does not have a leading './' or '/'.
Returns:
The TextFile representing the first file found matching the given name. If nothing is found and the file is read only or some other problem occurs, NULL is returned.

BinaryFile* FileSystem::openBinaryFile ( const string &  name,
OpenMode  openFlags = ReadWrite,
SearchOrder  order = CurrentDir_ResourceLocs 
)

Creates a new BinaryFile based on the given OpenMode and SearchOrder. If the given file doesn't have a leading './' or '/', the file is searched for according to the given SearchOrder. If the file is found that matches the name, a BinaryFile will be created and returned. If no file is found, one of two things will happen. If the file is opened for writing, a new file will be created in the current working directory, otherwise NULL is returned.

Parameters:
name The name of the file to try and open for reading.
openFlags Flags to be passed to the BinaryFile constructor.
order Dictates where the library should look for a matching file and the order it should look in. This only matters if the given name does not have a leading './' or '/'.
Returns:
The BinaryFile representing the first file found matching the given name. if nothing is found and the file is read only or some other problem occurs, NULL is returned.

void FileSystem::setCurrentDirectory ( const string &  dir  ) 

Sets the current directory for the library. The current directory is prepended to the beggining of path arguments of certain functions in the library.

Note:
The current directory is prepended to the input if no leading './' or '/'. i.e. The current dir is "./foo/" and you call setCurrentDirectory("bar"), the new current directory will be ./foo/bar/.
Parameters:
dir 

void FileSystem::addResourceLocation ( const string &  dir  ) 

Adds a resource loction to the library.

Note:
The current directory is prepended to the input if no leading './' or '/'.
Parameters:
dir The new location to add. May be a directory or a package file.

void FileSystem::removeResourceLocation ( const string &  dir  ) 

Removes the names resource location from the library.

Note:
The current directory is prepended to the input if no leading './' or '/'.
Parameters:
dir The name of the location to remove. Must match exactly!

void FileSystem::clearResourceLocations (  ) 

Removes all resource locations from the library.
